The next generation of Buffetts will have 10 years to give the money away. Warren Buffett has been donating large sums to the Gates Foundation and his family foundations, but has now decided to give his entire fortune to his children. They have already given away over $15 billion since 2006 and have built enduring institutions in their foundations. The tight timeframe to give away his fortune reflects one of Warren Buffett's longstanding conditions for receiving charitable funding. The next generation of Buffetts have run their foundations with tiny staffs, but have created strong relationships with other organizations to help implement their ideas.

news knowledge.eng_title: Walton Family Surpasses $100 Billion in Wealth for the First Time
news knowledge.summary: The Walton family has surpassed $100 billion in wealth for the first time, according to Bloomberg's billionaire index. Jim Walton, 76, the son of founder Sam Walton, leads the way with a net worth of $102.6 billion, followed closely by his brother Rob, 79, with a net worth of $100.4 billion. Their sister Alice, 74, is not far behind with a net worth of $99.7 billion. The family's net worth has increased by nearly $30 billion this year, with the three siblings adding $89 billion to their combined wealth. The family has been secretive about their wealth, but have recently started investing in various new ventures. Rob Walton made headlines in 2022 by purchasing the Denver Broncos for $4.65 billion, while the family has also invested in redeveloping their hometown of Bentonville, Arkansas, into an arts and sports complex. Walmart's stock has risen 53% this year, driven by the company's e-commerce growth and efforts to attract more middle-class customers. The stock has reached an all-time high of $80.60 per share, but has not changed much on Monday's trading in New York. None of the three heirs are involved in the day-to-day operations of the company or sit on Walmart's board of directors, with Rob Walton having retired earlier this year and Jim Walton serving as the head of the Arvest Bank Group, a regional lender with over 260 branches in three states. Alice Walton, a passionate art collector, recently surpassed L'Oréal heiress Françoise Bettencourt Meyers to become the world's richest woman.

news knowledge.eng_title: Alice Walton Becomes World's Richest Woman, Surpassing Françoise Bettencourt Meyers
news knowledge.summary: Alice Walton, daughter of Walmart founder Sam Walton, has become the world's richest woman for the first time since May 2022, according to Forbes' real-time billionaires ranking. She surpassed Françoise Bettencourt Meyers, heir to L'Oréal, on Wednesday, September 4. Walton's 74-year-old fortune is estimated at $89.2 billion. Françoise's fortune, which briefly reached $100 billion in June, is now estimated at $87.6 billion. According to Forbes, Walmart's shares have risen 47% this year, while L'Oreal's shares have fallen 13% in the same period. Alice Walton now ranks 18th on the list of the world's richest people, with her brothers Jim Walton ($95.9 billion) and Rob Walton ($94.3 billion) ranking 15th and 16th, respectively. The heirs own nearly 46% of the company founded by their father, according to Forbes. 'Forbes estimates that three-quarters of the family's shares are divided equally between Alice Walton and her brothers Jim and Rob Walton,' the publication says. The remaining fortune belongs to the heirs of her brother John Walton, who passed away in 2005: his widow, Christy Walton, and his son, Lukas Walton, who have fortunes of $16.4 billion and $33.9 billion, respectively. Alice Walton worked briefly at Walmart as a children's clothing buyer after graduating from Trinity University in Texas in 1971. She then turned to art curation. She presided over the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art for a decade before handing over the reins to Olivia Walton, the wife of her nephew Tom Walton, in 2021. In recent years, Alice has focused on philanthropy and invested over $5.7 billion in five family charity foundations, according to Forbes.
